replies.msg:
The instrumental version is better than the version with lyrics. The songs fits much better for instrument then for choral work.

The vocing and lyrics are quite weak in the beginning since it dies down at the end of phrase. I guess we need to think more about the rhyme and diction may not match that well into the melody pattern expecially on some areas with semiquavers and at the end of a descending melodic phrase.

Understanding the intention of your first part of the song is to show the mood of frustration , but I feel like it is too dragging. It may be caused by lower pitch, square rhythms , repeated long-short-dotted, etc..

I personally almost lost attention when I sing or listen to first part. It 's like funeral march.. At this time, I hope people need a song that is uplifting which I only see in pretty later part of the song.

I hope you can enhance the melodic and rhymthmic pattern: I kind of lost of direction when I hear the song. If you want it upbeat and march like , then many descending long notes ( 8th notes on b.10) putting on climax area cancelled that drive! If you want the song kind of dancing like, then I don't undertand why there are lots of half notes which may reduce that effect.

It is very hard for listeners and singers to pause and reflect on words when the notes disappear too fast. There are lots of semiquavers ( maybe over 30). It is really hard to sing clearly and sometimes it comes with an extreme jump ( for group singing) of a 7th in b.21. The cantonese is very tricky. so it is a challenge on puttting that into weak and fast semiquavers but need to rhyme it too.

My suggestion is to make the song more simple. One idea is to introduce more dotted 4th combined with 8th note, maybe using the Moderato. With a streak of ascending and descending quavers( 8th notes), or 4th notes, set up by some dotted notes. It can help building the DRIVE or relax after the climax.

Use KISS principle. Keep it simple... Instead of bring so many musical elements such as instrumental, cut it down for choral work !!! A strong suggestion will increase number of repated stanzas !!

The range is way too much for an amateur: From G (bar 4) to high D (bar 16). A jump from G to F on bar 21 is ok for trained solo only. I would suggest the highest will be E and stay within an octave. I like the triplets though !!

This is a good piece of music for instrument , but not quite good for group vocals !

It is a very good try. Lots of effort are put in !!! I hope the current version can keep improving.

Thanks for allll your effort !!!
